Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research in Political Science: Electoral Competition and the Provision of Rural Public Goods in Sub-Saharan Africa

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research investigates the claim that democracy increases the provision of rural public goods in sub-Saharan Africa. This assertion follows the theoretical argument that competitive elections in Africa create incentives for politicians to target resources towards the rural majority in order to win votes. The claim that public goods distribution is responsive to electoral incentives contrasts with the prevailing wisdom in the literature, that democracy is irrelevant in Africa. Rather than being solely determined by corruption, or clientelism, or ethnic voting, this dissertation project asserts that elections do matter, in that they make politicians responsive to the preferences of voters.

Building on evidence from cross-national statistical analyses, the investigator proposes to carry out a program of quantitative and qualitative research within a single country (Ghana). The primary objectives of this research are: (1) to construct an original spatial dataset combining election results and indicators of public goods such as healthcare, education, and infrastructure; and (2) to collect a body of rich, contextually-based qualitative evidence regarding the allocation and distribution of these public goods. This necessitates the collection and collation of data from various offices of the Electoral Commission of Ghana, as well as the Ministry of Finance and the Department of Feeder Roads. Qualitative evidence will be garnered from archival work and interviews with political elites throughout Ghana. The evidence resulting from this research will enable evaluation of the predicted relationship between elections and public goods, and examination of the suggested causal pathways underlying this relationship.

The proposed research will make a crucial contribution to our understanding of how democracy affects the provision of public goods. Existing literature on this topic suggests a positive effect, but is inconclusive. By offering a novel theoretical argument for why democracy affects public goods provision, the proposed research makes a claim about when and how the effect of democracy should be felt. This paves the way for a more precise and robust evaluation of the effect of democracy on public goods than has previously been undertaken. The complementary aspects of the proposed mixed-methods research have been designed so as to make possible a full investigation of both the predictions and internal workings of the theoretical argument.

As well as advancing the understanding of the effect of democracy, the project will broaden the focus of inquiry by recognizing the interests of rural as distinct from urban citizens. In so doing, it will bring into analytical focus an often overlooked and underrepresented group. Moreover, by focusing on urban-rural differences in political preferences and public goods provision, the research directly addresses a crucial issue affecting social relations across the world today: urbanization. The growth of urban populations is rapidly changing the nature of global demography; this research will generate knowledge of how urban-rural cleavages affect politics, which is critical for understanding the effects of urbanization. Rapid urbanization is also affecting the nature of poverty, as it becomes an increasingly urban phenomenon. By focusing on the urban-rural dimension of politics in Africa, the project will make a vital contribution to contemporary debates about development and poverty reduction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The fieldwork made possible by this Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant was designed to investigate the relationship between elections and rural public goods provision in Ghana. This contributes to a broader dissertation project, which focuses on the effects of democracy on public goods provision across sub-Saharan Africa. The broader project contributes to the literature on the effects of democracy on public goods, as well as advancing our understanding of political competition and behavior in Africa by recognizing hitherto largely ignored urban-rural dynamics. The fieldwork had two main components. First, it involved collecting the information necessary to construct a detailed geographically-coded dataset on election results and public goods indicators (including road conditions and aspects of village infrastructure such as water and electricity provision), from the Ghanaian Electoral Commission and various government ministries in Accra. This dataset enables rigorous statistical analysis of the relationship between elections and public goods in Ghana. Moreover, it provides a unique, original resource with which to investigate the effects of political competition in sub-Saharan Africa. Second, the project involved in-depth interviews with political and bureaucratic elites throughout Ghana. This qualitative research provides a rich body of contextual evidence, against which to assess the validity of the results of the quantitative analyses.

Preliminary findings suggest that electoral outcomes in Ghana are significantly and substantially affected by the provision of public goods. More specifically, changes to local road conditions have a powerful impact of presidential vote shares. This effect is most pronounced in marginal or “swing” areas, where a one standard deviation improvement in road conditions relates to an increase in the incumbent party’s presidential vote share of more than five percentage points. In addition, the analysis has shown that this effect on votes is not uniform across all public goods, but rather is limited to those which can be attributed to political effort. In Ghana responsibility for education inputs falls at various different levels of government, which means that it is not possible for citizens to hold the executive directly responsible for these inputs. As a result, we should expect education inputs to have less of an impact on electoral outcomes than do road conditions, for which the executive is directly responsible. The findings support this expectation – education inputs have no significant impact on presidential vote shares.  As the analysis progresses, I will investigate the impact of electricity and water provision on votes.

The primary findings of my research are important to political science because the received wisdom about electoral politics in Africa is that voter choice is dominated by clientelist ties, or ethno-regional loyalties, or some combination of the two. As such, the idea that citizens in Africa actually use elections to hold politicians accountable for the provision of public goods and services has been largely dismissed. This research provides evidence that, although clientelism and ethnicity are certainly important, they are not the only factors that determine voter choice. The recognition that public goods may also play a part thus challenges the model of electoral politics that has dominated studies of political competition in Africa. Beyond political science, this project has the potential to contribute to policy aimed at encouraging human and economic development in Africa as well as other developing regions.
